Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.2d 1232 (Mass. 1977)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant's failure to provide and maintain electricity in the bedroom constitutes a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.support_reasoning: The provided text is a short concurring opinion by an Indiana judge dealing solely with intra-court case reassignment and the authority of a chief judge to reassign cases within a multijudge court. It does not address Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, implied covenants of quiet enjoyment, or electrical service in a rental unit. The citation to 363 N.E.2d 1232 here is merely a reporter reference and not related to the stated proposition, so this opinion does not support the claimed legal principle.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 N.E.relevant_excerpt: "The two trial judges sitting upon appellant’s case were at all times relevant hereto judges of the same court, namely, the Superior Court of Lake County, a multijudge court. It was well within the authority of Judge Richards, acting pursuant to Ind. Code § 33-5-29.5-19, as Chief Judge of that court to take temporary assignment of one of Judge Letsinger’s cases during his illness, and after Judge Letsinger’s return to work to reassign the case to Judge Letsinger."

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, failed to provide and maintain electricity in one of the bedrooms of the apartment, rendering the room uninhabitable for approximately six weeks.

Puffer v. Flint, 66 Mass. 101, 103 (Mass.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant's failure to provide and maintain electricity in the bedroom constitutes a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Puffer v. Flint, 66 Mass. 101, 103 (Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion in Puffer v. Flint concerns evidentiary rules about refreshing a witness’s recollection and the proper allocation of the burden of proof in a dispute over impounded animals. It does not address landlord-tenant law, implied covenants, quiet enjoyment, or the provision or maintenance of utilities such as electricity. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that failure to provide bedroom electricity breaches the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Puffer v. Flint, 66 Mass. 101, 103 (Mass.relevant_excerpt: As soon as that was done, the custody of them passed to the pound-keeper, and from thence until the arrival of the day, fixed by precise and positive provisions of law when a further official duty was to be performed by the defendants, they had no care of, and could exercise no control over the animals, and would not have been responsible for them if they had all perished in the pound for want of necessary care or of adequate supplies of food.

Tarini v. Sullivan, 595 N.E.2d 1088 (Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Tarini v. Sullivan, 595 N.E.2d 1088 (Mass. 1992), but an Illinois criminal case (People v. May or similar) concerning attempted murder, aggravated battery, and armed robbery. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or any issue regarding the provision or maintenance of electricity in a rental unit. Therefore, it cannot support the stated Massachusetts implied covenant of quiet enjoyment proposition.
Tarini v. Sullivan, 595 N.E.2d 1088 (Mas.relevant_excerpt: The entire opinion concerns a criminal prosecution for attempted murder, aggravated battery, and armed robbery under Illinois law and discusses issues of voluntariness of statements, sufficiency of evidence, and sentencing. It contains no discussion of landlord-tenant relations, habitability, or quiet enjoyment.
